Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Dear Lord, thank you for your generosity in providing us today with this bountiful feast.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Thank you for the many gifts that you have given me. Thank you for your protection and your guidance. Thank you for bringing me this far. I know my long journey's end is near. I ask now only for the strength and the courage to complete the task that you in your infinite wisdom saw fit to bestow upon me over all men. I won't let you down. Amen.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Hey. You hungry?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Come on now.

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: Oh. Please don't hurt me. Here, take anything you want. You want some food? Take it.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm not going to hurt you.

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: That's what the last guys said.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: Could you help me? The wheel came off. I can't fix it. Maybe if I could get it out of the ditch. But I can't.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: One good thing about no soap any more. You can smell the road agents a mile off.

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: Dumb bitch. What did we tell you?

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: What you got there in the pack?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: Yeah, that's what they all say. How about you take it off real slow and tip it out so's we can take a look?

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: Shit, it ain't loaded. They never are. Ain't that right, old man?  Open the fucking pack or die.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I can't do that.

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: Want us to do it for you? We can get it off real easy after we've hacked your fucking arms off.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's real important you boys listen to me and understand. The man I work for, you do not want to cross him. See, I'm under his protection. You stand in my way, you stand in his. And he will cut you down with a righteous fury - through me. For I am his faithful instrument.

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: What the hell are you, some kinda preacher?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Something like that.

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: Well I got news for you, preacher man. Whatever kinda God you reckon yourself to be working for, he left these parts a long time ago. He ain't here to protect your ass. Now take off the pack and set it on the ground.

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: You fucking listening to me?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I hear you. You lay that hand on me again and you will not get it back.

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: All right, I had just about enough of this shit...

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: What... you just... he just cut my fucking hand off! My fucking hand!

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: What you standin' around for? Kiss him!

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: He's in shock. He means "kill him".

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I told you you wouldn't be getting that back.

Speaker: bandit leader
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: My name is Eli.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Take it and go on your way. And don't fall in with men like these again. No good can come.

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: Why are you doing this?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: God, the father of mercies, through the death and resurrection of his son has reconciled the world to himself and sent the holy spirit among us for the forgiveness of sins.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Through the ministry of the church may he give you pardon and peace, and I absolve you from your sins in the name of the father, and of the son, and of the holy spirit. Amen.

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: Thank you. You're... a good man.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: There are no good men on the road.

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: West.

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: Can... can I come with you?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It ain't your concern. Stay on the path. It ain't your concern. Stay on the path.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You got an engineer or a fuelman around here?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: I don't know you.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm not from around here.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: No shit. Who are you?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm just a customer.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: A customer with a shotgun?

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: You come in here to rip me off?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: No. I'll set it down. Okay?

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: Slowly!

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: You carry a gun in the outland, you don't bring one into town less you live there. Don't you know that?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm sorry, I forgot. I've been on the road a long time.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: Show me your hand.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm not a-

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: I said show me your fucking hand!

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm not one of them.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm just passing through. I need some help. I can pay.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: What kinda help? And what kinda pay?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm going to get something out of my pack. Okay?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I know, I know. Slowly.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: Holy shit.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: Where'd you find this?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Years ago, in the outland back east aways.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: Does it work?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Yeah, it just needs a charge. Can you do it? I got the cables.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: Depends if you also got the coin.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: It'll take a couple hours. There's a bar across the street you can wait, they just opened up.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'll wait here.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: You don't trust me?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I don't know you.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: Survey team just finished up their inspection. It ain't good.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: How bad is it?

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: Pressure is down again, and going by the new rod they sank levels're lower than they've ever been.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: How long?

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: Hard to say. Six months, maybe. A little longer if we're careful. But we're already-

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Halve the rations.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: We just halved `em last-

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: So halve them again!

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: You're going to have to say something. Folks were none too happy last time. Gonna be worse now, you can count on it.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I want you all to remember how far we've come together. And how far we still can go, if only we believe. When I brought us here to this oasis - this promised land - we knew there would be hardships. Knew there would be sacrifices. But we also knew that we were creating for ourselves a world where we could be safe from the horrors of the forsaken lands beyond our borders.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: And I want you all to remember above all that it is not the water with which we have been blessed that is the true lifeblood of this town... but faith.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: It is our faith that sustains us, brothers and sisters! Hallelujah!

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: And mark me, the ultimate validation of that faith is coming! The sacred Word of Our Lord that formed the world before and will reform it once again is coming to this town to bring it succor, bring it nourishment, bring it new life! For the Almighty Himself has spoken unto me and promised it!

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: In the meantime, He has asked us all to be patient. To walk the hard road of the faithful just a little longer. And to do that, we must give just a little more.  Water rations will be halved until further notice.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I understand your frustration. The road to salvation is a difficult one - but what lies at the end of that road is a greater glory, beyond anything you can imagine.

Speaker: discontented villager
Dialogue: We've heard this all before! When are you going to-

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I know each and every one of you will understand the necessity of this action. It was faith that built this town - and faith that will sustain it even through the dark times that may lie ahead. But it is always darkest before dawn - and the new dawn is coming.  May God go with you all.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: One of the road crews just rolled into town.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Of course they did, the bar's open. Outlanders, always looking for answers at the bottom of a bottle.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: Not these guys.  These guys say they got something.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Get them up here now.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Gentlemen! It's truly a delight to see you again! I understand your latest excursion into the outland has been a profitable one?

Speaker: hog
Dialogue: We did good.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Well, let's see, shall we?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: No. No. No. No. No.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: It's not here.

Speaker: hog
Dialogue: These ain't worth nothin'?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: When you bring me the book I asked you for, it'll be worth something.

Speaker: hog
Dialogue: We been doin' this a long time now. Had to make a whole lotta corpses to bring you all these books. You want us to keep at it, reckon it's worth more than a few free glasses of that swill you call liquor.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Gentlemen, gentlemen. I urge you once again to take the long view here. When we find this book - and believe me, we will find it - we are going to build a new world. A world far greater, far more righteous than this one. And you and I are going to be perched right on top of it, looking down upon it, masters of all creation!

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: And you know, I think you're absolutely right.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: The book I want is out there somewhere, just waiting to be found. Once there were millions of copies - you only need to find one! Find it and bring it here. And I promise you, you will be rewarded beyond anything you can imagine.

Speaker: hog
Dialogue: This better not be bullshit.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: Might help if they knew just what they were looking for.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Not one of them can read. How would they even know when they found it?

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: So how's about you just tell me?

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: Two years now you been sending these crews into the outland. Burning up gas we can barely spare. For a goddamn book? What the hell kinda book can be worth all this?

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: What about these?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Put them with the others.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: What's this place across the street? They got any water?

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: We got our own underground spring here. Only fresh water in a hundred miles - if's you can pay for it.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'll be back.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: If that battery ain't here when I get back, I will use this gun on your kneecaps and I will put this building to the torch and I will watch it burn to the ground with you alive inside it. So help me God.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Is that you, honey?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Something wrong?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: More books came in from the road today.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Oh? It's been a while.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: And it'll be a while longer. Just another pile of useless junk. If we don't find the right one soon - if I can't give these people what they want to hear...

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: You'll find what you're looking for. It's out there somewhere. You just have to have faith.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Faith? Is that what you think we're missing around here?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: My old man used to have faith. He had it in spades. My mother, too.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Faith is for the weak. It's for them out there, the sheep. This world is what you can see and touch and taste. It's what you make it. All these years with me, you still don't have any grasp of that? What's wrong with you, woman?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: No, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to scare you. Hey. You okay?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: You just get me all riled up with that kind of talk. It's not what I need from you right now.  You know what I need right now?

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Outlander? Let me see-

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: What'll it be?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Water.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: That's the good stuff. Gotta eat into my own ration to sell it - so I don't sell it cheap.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: That'll get you maybe half-way.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: What about that?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: That's the best I got.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Solara!

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Take this out back and get it filled.

Speaker: hog
Dialogue: That was my cat.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Fine specimen.

Speaker: hog
Dialogue: I saw you push him off the bar.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I didn't push him.

Speaker: hog
Dialogue: You raised your hand at him.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Sorry. It won't happen again.

Speaker: bartender
Dialogue: Hey, how about another drink, Hog?

Speaker: hog
Dialogue: That cat's been comin' in here for nigh on two years. It got more right to be here than you. Who the fuck do you think you are?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I don't want any trouble.

Speaker: hog
Dialogue: Well, that's too bad, `cause-

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I know you. Murderer of innocent travelers on the road. You're going to spend eternity drowning in a lake of fire for the things that you've done. Did you know that?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You go on back to your table and I'll be on my way. All right?

Speaker: burly patron
Dialogue: You push Hog, you push all of us.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Cursed be the ground because of you. By toil shall you eat of it. Thorns and thistles shall it sprout for you. From the ground were you taken. For dust you are.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: And to dust you shall return.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Did you hear that? What was that?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Maybe you should go check.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: What in the hell is going on?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Get your asses out here!

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Stop!

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Please don't.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Go.

Speaker: hog
Dialogue: ...What?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It ain't for me to judge you. Your time for that's gonna come. Believe me. Now go on. Get out of here.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm sorry for all the mess.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: So, who are you?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Nobody. A walker in the outland.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I've met walkers before. Not a particularly civilized bunch. Some have even taken to eating their own kind, did you know that? You wouldn't be one of those savages now, would you?

Speaker: carnegie gunman
Dialogue: He ain't got the shakes.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Good. This is a civilized town. Under God. Do you know what that means?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: It means we have laws here. Laws set down long before any of us ever walked this earth. And one of them is, you don't eat the flesh of your brother. Else you're no better than an animal. And not welcome here.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: So what's your business here, friend? Walkers don't usually come into town less they want something.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I had a battery needed charging and a canteen needed filling. I didn't come here looking for trouble.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Well, you sure as hell found it. Do you know who I am?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: My name's Carnegie. I own this bar. I own the whole town. You've never heard of me?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: That's you out there on the street.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Remarkable likeness, isn't it? You'd never guess half the men who built it were blind. A small tribute from a grateful people. I was deeply touched.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You had slaves build you a monument to yourself?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Don't call them slaves. That's an old word. I'm not a slaver. I'm trying to help these people.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: In the outland the sightless are preyed upon like sick animals. Here at least they're protected. They do the essential work others don't want. And in return they eat, they drink, they survive. Last year, a couple of them even got married - performed the ceremony myself.  You see, I'm not exploiting these people - I'm saving them! Any one of them is free to leave whenever they wish. But here they stay. And they thank me every single day for their salvation!

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's none of my business what you do here. Like you said, it's your town. I just want to be on my way.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: What's your name, walker?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: All right, I guess we just call you Walker. Don't see too many folks your age these days. You lived in the world before? You can read?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I read every day.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: That's good. Good man. We educated folk, we need to stick together, if we're ever going to rebuild this world. People like you and me, we're the future.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: What do you want with me?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Straight to the point. I like that. Fact is, you could be in a lot of trouble. This is a peaceful town. You walk in here, armed, and the next thing a dozen of my good citizens are dead. I've hanged men for less. I could hang you.  Or, you could come work for me.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I never once saw anyone handle themselves the way you did down there in that bar. I don't know where you learned it, but I sure as hell could use it.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm not interested.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: People who work for me can live better than any walker ever dreamed. Real beds, clean water, hot food. Women, even. You could do a lot worse, my friend.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm not your friend. And I'm not staying. I got someplace I need to be. Out west.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: West? There is nothing west. It's all gone, a long time ago.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I've been told different.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: By who?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: All right, look. I'm going to make you an offer of goodwill. Stay the night, think it over. Try a little local hospitality. We'll talk again in the morning. If you're still not interested, you're free to go. No hard feelings.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Thank you for your offer. But I'd prefer to just leave right now. So you can either let me out of here, or I can kill my way out.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Let him go.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: Oh, shit...

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: How's my battery?

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: It's, uh... it's gonna take a little longer than I thought.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: How much longer?

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: It's gotta charge overnight. You, uh, you can always stay here in town, pick it up in the morning.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You remember what I said would happen if I came back here and you didn't have my battery?

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: It's right here! It's just gonna take a while longer. I swear.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I knew you'd reconsider.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Yeah? How'd you know that?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: None of the walkers I've seen come here from the outland were ever what you'd call smart. I mean all those years out there alone on the road, some with their brains half- fried from eating each other - it's understandable why you people aren't the brightest bulbs in the box. But I never met one so dumb that he'd turn down a meal and a bed if it was offered.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: So you didn't send someone across the street to the engineer?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Engineer? I don't know what you're talking about. If there's something wrong, maybe I can help.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: This is Redridge. He's kind of my right-hand man around here.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: He'll show you to your room.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: Enjoy your stay. There'll be someone outside your room all night. If you need anything.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: I have this for you. Water for washing and some food.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Well... are you going to take it?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Oh. Thank you.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: You're very welcome.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: It'll be dark soon.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Can I get you anything else?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: No, thank you.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Well. Have a good night.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You're Carnegie's woman?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Why do you ask?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Just making conversation is all. Haven't had one of those in a while. Not a real one, leastways.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: He found me in the outland. I was sixteen, my family had been... well, they were gone. There was just me and my baby.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You had a baby?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: I'd met some men on the road. Bad men. They...

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's all right.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: I was on the road for a year after that. I couldn't feed myself, let alone my little girl. And then Bill found us and he promised he'd take care of us. He told me he was going to make a place where we could be safe. And he did. He did all that. He built this whole town. He kept us safe. And he raised that child like she was his own. He's been so good to both of us. He saved us, really.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You want to eat some?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: When did you go blind? In the war? You get caught in a flash?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: No, I was born this way. I think I'm lucky like that.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Lucky?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: It's not like I ever knew what I'm missing. I was already used to being like this by the time... by the time it all happened. So I got around pretty good even when I was on my own. And now it's easy. I know every creaky old floorboard in here, and it's not like I ever go any place else. Bill would never allow it. He worries about me so much.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: I should go. He'll be wondering where I am.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Thank you. I enjoyed our conversation.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: So did I.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: You took your time in there. How long does it take to deliver a plate of food and some water?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: He wanted to talk.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Oh? What about?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Nothing really. He asked me what it was like to be blind.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: He tell you anything about him?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: No. I don't think he likes to talk about himself much.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Yeah, I got that.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: I don't think he's going to change his mind by morning. I don't think he's going to stay.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: What makes you say that?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Just strikes me as the kind of man who's of a mind, is all. Doesn't seem like the type to go changing it once it's set.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Well, we'll just see about that.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: You saw him. He's not like the others. You won't be able to smooth- talk him and wrap him around your finger like you usually do.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Who said anything about me?  I'm sending Solara.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: You're doing what? CARNEGIE You know how often these walkers get laid? Never. Least not by anything living or willing. Girl like her can be very persuasive.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: You can't send her in there with him. He's dangerous, he's a killer!

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: You went in there readily enough.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: That's different. Solara's just a child, she can't-

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: She's a grown woman now, Claudia. Sooner or later you're going to have to accept that. She has to earn her keep around here, same as the rest of us.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: By working as a whore? That's all you think she's fit for?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: We've each been given a talent to help us make our way in this world. Some people's gift is more evident than others. Solara's sure as hell is.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: What kind of a man are you?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I'm the kind of man who'd pull a helpless blind girl off the road, a girl who'd been beaten and raped, and give her a place where she can live without fear! Without me you'd be just another no-eye, lying dead in the outland, picked clean by the buzzards, or shoveling dirt down there with the others. That's the kind of man I am!

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: I don't live without fear. I haven't for a long time now.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: I'm not going to let you do this.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: You're not going to let me?  Nobody tells me what I can and can't do in my own town. Nobody. I built this world, and I am God here! So don't go thinking about screwing with my plans. You know how this works. Solara goes against me, you get hurt. You go against me, she gets hurt.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: So let's not see anybody get hurt. Okay?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Hi. Can I come in?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Someone was already here with food and water. I got everything I need.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: You sure about that?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: It's too bright in here. Mind if I turn it down a little?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: That's better. I'm Solara. You're Walker, right?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: No. My name's Eli.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: That short for something? Elias?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Elijah.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Elijah. I never heard that one before. It's kinda cute.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Look, I don't mean to be rude. But I'm really not interested.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: You sure about that? It gets mighty lonely out there on the road.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: If you're worried about money, this is all paid for. The whole night.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's not that. You're a very nice girl. But I'm not that kind of man.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: They're all that kind of man. He moves her hand away. Gently pushes her back a step.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm not.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: They told me you were crazy. Maybe they were right.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Good night.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Please don't make me leave. I have to stay the night. If I don't...

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: If you don't, what?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: He'll hurt my mom.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Who will? Carnegie?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Maybe he and I oughta have words.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: No! Please, don't!

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: He's hurting you. He's hurting your mother. He's-

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: He's my dad.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Look, if you want to help me, just let me stay here tonight. We don't have to do anything. I'll sleep on the floor. Tomorrow you can tell my dad that we had a good time. I'll be no trouble, I swear.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You want to have a conversation?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You know, you don't have to be afraid of me. What happened down there in the bar...

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I'm not afraid of you. I know you didn't start that trouble. When I first saw you, I knew you weren't the type to go looking for it.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: How'd you know that?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: My mom says I'm a good judge of character. She says I can read people. That I know a good man when I see one.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: So... you're pretty old, right?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I just mean, I haven't seen too many people your age. How old are you exactly?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You know, I don't rightly remember.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: But you're old enough. I mean, you remember what it was like? In the world before?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: What was it like?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Better than this.  People lived longer back then. Longer than me. Some were more than a hundred years old.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I swear, it's true. Nowadays it's not the same. If you're sick or you're weak or you're old you won't last long out on the road.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: So how come you have?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Can I read you something?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Wait. You can read?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: And you have a book? ELI Not just any book.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: The Lord is my shepherd. I shall not want. He makes me lie down in green pastures. He leads me beside still waters. He restores my soul. He leads me in the paths of righteousness.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil. For you are with me. Your rod and your staff, they comfort me. You prepare a table before me in the presence of my enemies. You anoint my head with oil. My cup runs over. Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me, all the days of my life. And I will dwell in the house of the Lord forever.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: That's beautiful. Did you write that?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: What book is it from? Is it poetry?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I guess you could think of it that way. It's from the Holy Bible.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I never heard of it. What's it about?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's about love, and forgiveness, and life and death, and mercy, and revenge, and the beginning and the end of the world. I guess it's about a little bit of everything.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Can I see?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: What? I'm not going to do anything.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I'm charged to protect this book. I can't trust it with anyone. Not even for a while.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: What's so special about that book?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's the last one. There are no other books like this. All the others are gone - destroyed by the war or in the burnings that came after. This is the only one that survived until now. The last one anywhere.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: How can you know that?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I just know.  For a long while after it happened, I just wandered on the road like most everybody else. There were still a lot of people around back then, in the beginning. I didn't really know what I should do or where I was going. I was just moving from place to place, trying to stay alive. And then one day I heard this voice. I don't know how to explain it, it's like it was coming from inside me. But I could hear it, clear as day. Clear as I can hear you talking to me now.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: What did it say?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It led me to this place, I don't really know where. And I found this book buried deep under some rubble. No way no-one was ever going to find it if they didn't know exactly where to look.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: But you knew because the voice told you?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: That's right. And that voice told me to carry the book west.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Because a voice you heard in your head told you to.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm not crazy. I didn't imagine it. I know what I heard.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: So who was it? The voice?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: A very important, very powerful man.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: More powerful than my dad?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I should say so, yes.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Would you teach me to read?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I never learned. No-one around here knows how. Only my dad, and he won't teach me. I think he likes being the only one who can read. I think it makes him feel powerful.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I think you're probably right.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: So would you teach me?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I'm leaving tomorrow. And I won't be back this way, ever.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Are you hungry?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I guess a little.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: There's some food on the table over there. Let's eat.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's okay, it's okay. He's with me.  Don't be afraid, pal. This is Solara. She's our friend.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's okay. It means he likes you.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: It does? ELI Trust me, if he didn't like you, you'd know about it.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Did you really mean that?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Mean what?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: That I'm your friend.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Our father, we thank you for this meal which you have been so gracious to place before us.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: We thank you for a warm bed and a roof over our heads on a cold night such as this.  And we thank you for the gift of friendship in these hard times.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Amen.  You say that last part too.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Amen. And now we eat?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: And now we eat.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Good morning, Solara.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I said good morning, Solara.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Morning, dad.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: How was your night? Did you sleep well?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I did like you asked. Isn't that what you really want to know? Just come out and say it.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: You don't speak to your father like that. When I ask you a civil question, I expect a civil answer.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Did he say anything?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: No. We didn't talk much.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Well, do you think you managed to change his mind about staying?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I don't know. He said he had to go.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: So he did talk? What else did he say? Come on, I want all of it!

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: That's all he said. That he was going to be leaving this morning.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: We'll see. This is my town, nobody leaves until I say they leave.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: Solara, honey, eat something.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Our father, thank you for this meal which you have been so gracious to place before us.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Thank you for my mother. Please watch over her and keep her safe.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Solara...

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Thank you for all the-

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Solara! She snaps suddenly out of it, looks at her father.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: What the hell are you doing?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: God didn't put this food on the table. Do you hear me?  Who put this food on the table?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I said who put this food on the table?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: You did.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Who taught you that?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Eli taught me.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Who the hell is Eli?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: The walker. That's his name.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: And he taught you how to say those words? How did he know them?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: He had them written down in a book.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: What kind of a book?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I don't remember! It was an old leather book. It had kind of a... thing on the front of it.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Show me.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: He had a bible?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: That's what it was. A holy bible. Daddy, what's wrong? Did I...

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: Something wrong, boss?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Something wrong? Something wrong? The walker's gone!

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: That can't be. I had a man outside his room the whole time.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: He jumped out the window, you idiot! You didn't think to put a man outside the fucking window?  Find him. Now!

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: Boss, he could be anywhere. He...  A battery. Didn't he say something about a battery?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Go! Go!

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It ain't your concern. Stay on the path.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Dammit...

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Let her go.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: That cannon of yours casts a pretty wide net. I don't reckon you can hit me without hitting her.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I reckon you're right.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: This, though? With this I'll shave the hairs clean off your balls at a hundred paces. You believe me?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I believe you. I have to say I'm surprised to hear that language coming from you, though. I mean, you being a holy man and all.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: She told me all about it. Told me all about the bible, too.  Can I see it?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: You know, I've been searching for a book like that one for years. All I've ever wanted was to bring the word of God to these poor unfortunates here. To shine its light upon them and give them something in this wretched world that they could believe in. Something to live for! It's why I built this town, did you know that? All we've been missing is the word to show us the way. And now, praise the Lord, you've brought it to us.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: It's not right to keep that book hidden away, all to yourself. The word is meant to be shared with others. It's meant to be spread! Isn't that what you want? I could help you do that. You and me, we could do it together.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: The Lord himself told me that if I carried this book west, one day I would find the place where it was needed. Where it would be safe. Where it belonged.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: But this ain't it.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: What? What is it?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You shall not make for yourself any graven image...

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Now we can go.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Where are we going?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I told you where I'm going. You're free to go wherever you want.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Wait... I'm not coming with you?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You're only going to slow me down.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: So what the hell was all that about back there?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: The man was hurting you. I don't like that, so I put a stop to it. Now you're free. He can't hurt you any more.  No need to thank me.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Thank you? For what? What am I supposed to do now?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Whatever you want. That's what being free is.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Whatever I want. Except go with you.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I have to get where I'm going. I can't be worrying about someone else along the way.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I thought you were my friend.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's dangerous in the outland. I wouldn't want you to get hurt.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I'll be safe so long as I'm with you. I know it.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You don't want this life. I gotta do what I gotta do. Don't have no choice in it. But you do. And I can't let you choose this. You don't want to be like me. You don't want to spend your life alone.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: If I came with you, I wouldn't be alone. And neither would you.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Look, maybe it's best you just go on back to town.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Fine! I'll do just that! I had a life there! A family! I didn't ask you to save me! I didn't ask you for anything!

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Thank you, darling.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: He killed four of my men and walked out of town without a scratch. They shot off a hundred rounds at him and he didn't get hit once. I never even heard of anything like that.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: You know, I always thought of myself as a shepherd. Bringing together the wayward and the lost. Tending to my flock. But all the things I want to do, I can't do them on my own. The one thing I've needed is the one thing that's always been missing. Then one day it walks right into town - so close I can almost touch it - and then walks right on out again.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I want you to put a crew together and go out after him.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: He's not going to work for you. I think he's made that plain.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: I'm not interested in him any more. I only want the book he's carrying.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: If I'm gonna risk my ass hunting down this maniac in the outland, I need to know it's gonna be worth it. I need to know what's so special about this goddamn book.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: You have no idea. You're too young, you don't remember the world before. But I do. I remember.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: When I was a kid my parents used to read that book every goddamn day. My mother, she'd read it along with this smooth-talking preacher on the TV screen. They used to be able to beam these guys right into your house, into every house in the world, through the air. Like magic.  She worked two jobs and she sent every spare penny she had to that fucking guy on the TV. My old man, he'd read that book, then he'd get liquored up and kick my ass, tell me all about the power and the glory and how I was going to burn forever in hell for the sins I was born with. He made sure he beat it into me good.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Don't you see? It's not just any book.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: Boss... we're running out of water and the people are running out of patience. You're trying to tell me that a book is going to keep them in line?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Oh, it'll do much more than that. The water in this town may run dry, but faith - that springs eternal! And that faith will help turn this town into a city. And this city into a nation. It will help me build a new world. In my image. People will come from far and wide to hear what's inside of it. They'll follow me anywhere just to get a taste of it. And they'll do whatever I tell them.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: And what if this book don't work? What if it don't say what you want it to say?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Oh, it'll say what I want, I can promise you that. Because I'm going to rewrite it. I'll keep the parts that work for me and make the rest whatever I need it to be.  A new bible, for a new world.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: What do you think, darling? A whole new world, to do with as we will. Won't that be grand?

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Find that book.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: He has half a day on us already.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: So use the motor pool.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: There ain't much gas in reserve.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Whatever there is, use it.

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: What about Solara?

Speaker: claudia
Dialogue: She's still out there. With him.

Speaker: carnegie
Dialogue: Right. Right. Of course. Bring her back, too, if you can. But-

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: The book. I know.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Shit. Shit.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Where the hell am I?

Speaker: slumped female
Dialogue: Hello? Is anybody there?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Are you all right?

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: Oh. Yes, I'm fine. Thank you. You go along, I'll be okay.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: You look like you need some help.

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: No, really! I'm fine. Really... I need a man to help. Not you. You just keep along. Please.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: It'll just take a minute.

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: Really, it's fine! Please!

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: Let her go! She ain't got nothing!

Speaker: brigand leader
Dialogue: I ain't too sure about that.

Speaker: young woman
Dialogue: This wasn't the deal!

Speaker: brigand leader
Dialogue: Shut your mouth, bitch. You oughta be grateful you're getting a break.

Speaker: brigand leader
Dialogue: Never did care much for that dried- up old snatch anyhow.

Speaker: brigand leader
Dialogue: This one, though... this one looks fresh. You a virgin?

Speaker: brigand leader
Dialogue: Well, let's find out.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I offer you both one final chance in this life to seek forgiveness for your sins so that your souls may find salvation. Will you say with me the act of contrition?

Speaker: brigand leader
Dialogue: Fuck you.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Some might think it'd be most fitting to leave you here like this. Let you die slow in the sun. But I know better. I know where you're going. And the sooner you get there, the sooner you'll get what's coming to you.

Speaker: rifle bandit
Dialogue: Wait!

Speaker: rifle bandit
Dialogue: I want to say it. I want to be forgiven.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Repeat after me. Oh God, I am heartily sorry for having offended thee, and I detest all my sins.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I firmly resolve, with the help of thy grace, to confess my sins, and do penance, and to amend my life. Amen.

Speaker: rifle bandit
Dialogue: Amen...

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: You came back for me.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: What are friends for?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: This is the deal. You keep up. You pull your weight. You fall behind, I can't help you. Okay?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: What about her?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: There's nothing can be done for her.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: You killed it! That cute little thing!

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's good eating, is what it is.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: That's not funny.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: If you're going to be on the road, you can't be picky about what you eat. You eat what's there to eat.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I'm not eating that.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: More for me.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Father, we thank you for your generosity in providing us with this meal. Bless this food to our use and us to thy service, and keep us ever mindful of the needs of others. Amen.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: What does that taste like?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Tastes like chicken.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's a Saint Christopher medal.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Who's Saint Christopher? Is he a character from your book?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Christopher was a man who lived a long time ago. He wanted to be a good man, he wanted to help people. So he would stand by a river that had no bridge and carry people across. He was a big strong man and there was no one he couldn't carry.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Then one day a young child came to the river and asked to be carried across. Christopher tried to carry him but he was too heavy. He was just a small boy but he was heavier than any man he had ever carried. The boy explained that he was the son of God, and that he was so heavy because he bore all the sins of the world. After that, Christopher was able to carry him across and when they got to the other side the boy baptized him in the river. And that's how he became a saint. Later on, he was known as the patron saint of travelers.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: What is a saint, anyway?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's someone who spent their life doing good things for others. Enough that God himself took a special interest in them.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Someone like you.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: No. Not like me. Saints ain't killers. And I done too much of that. Spilled too much blood.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Will you read me some more from the book?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's late. You should get some sleep. Maybe tomorrow.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Eli?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: You scared me! I thought you were asleep.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: On the road you sleep with one eye open. I asked you what you were doing.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I just wanted to see the book.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You want to see the book, you ask me. Nobody touches it but me. Ever. Until it gets where it's going. Do you understand?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Tell me you understand!

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Okay! I understand! Ow!

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's no use to you anyway. You don't know how to read it.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Well... now we have the time, maybe you can teach me.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Maybe. Get some sleep.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: He's been here.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: The girl's with him.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: Move out!

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: I said move out!

Speaker: carnegie gunman
Dialogue: I heard this guy's protected somehow, some... power from up above. That there ain't nothing on this earth can touch him.

Speaker: redridge
Dialogue: He's just a man. You put a bullet in him, he'll go down like any other. I don't want to hear no more of this superstitious horseshit!

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: You say you've been walking for twenty-five years. Have you ever considered that you might be lost?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: But how can you know? How can you know this is the right way?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I told you. My path has been laid out before me.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Yeah, but laid out by who?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: By Almighty God.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Well if this God guy's so mighty, how come it's taking you so long to get where you're going? Doesn't he know the way?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: You want to stay on this road with me, don't ever let me hear you take his name in vain like that again.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: God has a reason for everything being the way it is. It's not always apparent to us. But it is his plan nonetheless.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: So, is he talking to you right now? Telling you where to go?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's not like that. It's kinda hard to explain. I'm guided by faith.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I don't know what that word means.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It means you know something even though you don't know it.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: That doesn't make any sense at all.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It doesn't have to.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: I don't get it. It looks almost... normal. Like nothing ever happened. How can it still be out here?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: Maybe we should look inside. There might be food.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Stay behind me.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: This is weird.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Shit.

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: elderly man
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: My name is Eli. This is Solara. We're travelers, that's all. We don't mean you any harm.

Speaker: elderly man
Dialogue: You cut my padlock. I saw you. Trying to break into our house.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: I'm sorry. We didn't think anybody lived here. We thought it was abandoned, like all the rest.

Speaker: elderly man
Dialogue: Take a look around you. Look at this yard. Does it look abandoned to you?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: No, sir. I... like what you've done with the place.

Speaker: elderly man
Dialogue: What's your business here?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: No business. We're sorry to have troubled you. If you'll let us down we'll happily be on our way.

Speaker: elderly woman
Dialogue: George, look at them! They're not robbers or road agents! One of them's just a girl!

Speaker: elderly man
Dialogue: Seen that before. Oldest trick in the book.

Speaker: elderly woman
Dialogue: Oh, stop! It's no trick. Let them down!

Speaker: elderly woman
Dialogue: I'm so sorry about my husband. We so rarely get visitors these days, he's suspicious of everybody.  I'm Martha and this is my husband George. Would you care for some tea?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: I'm afraid we don't have any cake or biscuits for the tea. They ran out some time ago.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: How do you like it?

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: It's.. uh...

Speaker: solara
Dialogue: It's very good.

Speaker: eli
Dialogue: Have you always lived here?

Speaker: martha
Dialogue: For almost forty years now. This home is our pride and joy, isn't it, George?
